description.text: Made this chess set for my son who is on a mission. I have it set up like this. The light side: Christ is king, the Holy Ghost dove is queen, the man id the suite is bishop, the missionary with the armor of God is the knight, the Temple is the Rook, the missionary name tags are the pawns. you can alter these with names of missionaries you know. The dark side: Death is the king, 7 head hydra dragon is the queen, the golden calf idol is the bishops, the natural man caveman is the knight, the worldly great and spacious building is the rook, the pawns are tombstones with bad thing on them. I als used a paint can lined with paper towels (held on by magnets) and 1/4 cup of acetone to wet the towel. I then set each piece on a small piece of aluminium on top of the paint can lid then covered the lid with the can. I let the vapors from the can work on the pieces from 40 to 60 minutes to make them glossy and smooth.

The servo Saver is a little spring we put between the servo and the actual direction, so if there's an accident, the wheels take the direct hit, but the servo don't  ( the servo saver, is cheaper than the actual servo, so if the spring brakes, u just lose direction )   
I was putting together my father's rc car and lost the original servo saver, It broke in a accident ( that's why it is there :) ) ... Since this is a vintage car, there's no official replacement, and I thought this would be a perfect challenge for the printer, It worked better than expected...

title: Epic Scale Eldar Revenant Titan Proxy

description.text:
An Eldar Revenant Titan proxy for Epic Armageddon or your local equivalent thereof.

Requires glue to assemble.

The files in here are for version2. almost everything has been beefed up a bit from original version which was more like the pictures but too flimsy. Now printed, the files printed without an issue.

there are some segments that are 'central' and you only need one of; head, torso, mid and legs.
there are some pieces that are ambidextrous; shoulders, hips.
and some that have left/right version; arms, jet packs.

it would be easy enough to repose i.e. the legs, by printing them out, cutting at the knees and gluing as required. can probably drop the individual leg segments in here if required but given the size of them they'd be a pain to print and position individually.

title: Speedy Car Fidget Spinner. Spin & Roll!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I had a suggestion posted on my Double Decker Fidget Spinner that it would be cool if I rotated the center bearing 90 degrees so the thing could also roll. This had been a consideration after I designed the Double Decker but I hadn't the time. Due to popular demand (of 1 person), here is the rolling fidget spinner. The extra weight of two bearings at each side make this thing spin faster than others and now, you can also play with it in a car like fashion. I've no doubt if you cleaned out and lubed all of your bearings for this make, it would roll very quickly. I haven't done that with mine yet but will. This also uses the 608 bearings.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Different filaments will print with ever so slightly different tolerances. This only affects the middle bearing which may need glueing in-place if it doesnt friction fit.

Carefully snap on the outer bearings, if you're too rough they might break! If you have shielded bearings, you will want to make a small modification to the middle one: Remove the shields, clean the bearing thoroughly and then lube with PTFE spray or similar. There are plenty of online tutorials of how to do this. If you want it to roll even faster, repeat this process for the other four bearings.

title: Mechanical CPU Clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The Mechanical CPU Clock shows the basic building blocks of a CPU (ALU, buses,RAM,registers, and a Control Unit). It executes a set of instructions which will emulate a simple wall clock.

The Mechanical CPU Clock shows the basic building blocks of a CPU (ALU, buses,RAM,registers, and a Control Unit). It executes a set of instructions which will emulate a simple wall clock. http://youtu.be/0H4LTOYpAM4 More information can be found here: http://www.liorelazary.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=46:mechanical-cpu-clock&catid=10:clocks&Itemid=15 and Here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Mechanical-CPU-Clock/ start building the clock by laser cutting the parts out of acrylic. You can use what ever color you like, but some colors show up better then others, so you should experiment. Once the pieces are cut, glue the track to the bottom of the clock using plastic weld on. The buses are made out of piano wire. Note the angle band at the top, which will be used to adjust the final length. Attach the buss wire to the flip-flops by forming an L band at the bottom. Attach the motor to the lifter and secure the clock with screws.

Text = Kirri

Pandebono 360: ideal para fotógrafos de Google Street View.

Rosca que te permitirá recoger las patas del trípode de manera equidistante, para que al realizar fotografías esféricas 360, las patas del trípode queden ocultas en el nadir de la fotografía.

Con este simple artefacto, el retoque del nadir será mucho más fácil porque las patas no saldrán en la parte inferior de la fotografía.

El trípode pierde estabilidad, pero seguirá sosteniéndose por sí mismo. Además, la idea de tomar una foto 360 es que el fotógrafo está siempre junto al trípode en todo momento. Se pierde estabilidad, pero se gana en tiempo de postproceso.

Sin el Pandebono 360, las patas del trípode no cerrarán de forma equidistante, lo que puede producir mucha inestabilidad.

Pandebono 360 es hardware libre, siéntete libre de descargar los planos, imprimirlo en 3D y mejorarlo.

Lista de Materiales

3 Tornillos de 3/16" x 33mm de largo
3 Tuercas de 3/16"

author: oxgon

description.text: This project that creates a chair from the shape of soap bubbles has recently been posted to Kickstarter. A soap bubble evenly distributes curvature throughout its shape, but at the same time equally distributes the structural forces as well. If you could harness this property for a structural system, you could use recycled materials and yield the same strength as high performance steel. Anyone who would like is welcome to print the file for themselves, but the model was created to be a reward for my kickstarter. Please take a look and contribute if you want to help out. http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1748240161/soap-bubble-chair Have a look at my website for more informational slide decks and videos that detail the ideas behind using the shape of a soap bubble in architecture and industrial design. http://www.mSurfaces.com
There are three registration holes in both the top and the bottom print. Print out both, and then lop off the head of a normal sewing pin to like them up into the whole.

description.text:
This replaces an encoder wheel on a SCORBOT RU4 robot Pittman motor. The openings are a little deeper than the ones on the actual machine. The original encoder wheel is held to the shaft with a 000 set screw; this model is a press fit. It needs to be printed in black or the encoder won't be able to distinguish the slots and it will read poorly. The encoders used on the robot no longer are available for purchase so this appears to be a viable solution for those of us still using these educational robots.

The picture I uploaded is the encoder built on an M3D using their carbon fiber filament. While not beautiful, with a little work with a file and razor blade, we got it to work. We printed a couple on better printers with better results, however, we don't have black filament at work so they would need to be painted before using.

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

High

Infill:

50%

Made in Autodesk Inventor. Designed by me.

I have no information about the printing process as of now, due to the fact that I'm new to 3D printing.

It printed well with the default settings on my Flashforge Finder.

I will add the Inventor files soon. Contact me if there is any need for changes to the design.

description.text:
We recently replaced an old hand held vacuum with a fancy new 'Lithium powered' Black & Decker model (Model No. HHVJ315JD10). After unboxing it, I realized that the only way to store the thing was to lay it down. Our old unit had a charging cradle that mounted to the wall, so we had it mounted up out of the way in a closet.

The new vacuum didn't have a mount, and Black & Decker doesn't make one for it either. I did notice that the underside of the vacuum had a slot that was angled upward. I measured it out and modeled up this mount. It attaches to the wall with two bugle head drywall screws. The vacuum is light enough that wall anchors are not required, but you may use them if so inclined.

author: JadenBrooks

title: Tube Mounting Clip - for 6.5mm tube, nail up

description.text:
This tube holder is designed to be nailed into position, securing tubes or hoses of nominally 6.5mm Outer Diameter.  
The actual internal diameter of the clip section is 6.8mm, to allow for printing tolerances. The offset toggle will apply pressure to the hose as the clip is nailed/screwed into position, allowing it to be used with 6mm - 6.8mm hoses while still applying pressure. The screw hole is 1.5mm diameter, suitable for small nails and screws.

Print as many as you need to hold up small tubes, etc. Mount using a 1 - 1.5mm nail or small diameter screw. The offset toggle means that pressure is applied to the hose when you nail it in position, making up for undersize tubes, etc not being gripped firmly by the clip. When printing this, I found that if my extrusion widths were two high, I ended up with a thin walled object, as it couldn't fit enough perimeters in, and the infill wasn't high enough to join the surfaces (see comments here: http://teslaandi.wordpress.com/2013/12/30/thin-profile-printing/ )

description.text:
This is a box to mount the Sanguinololu mainboard in.
Currently designed for the 1.3, and heavily WIP.
I intend to make it universal for multiple printers, but mostly for the mendel90 to be hung and clamped onto one of the frame parts.
I will make a lid with fan hole next (any fan type requests will probably be filled) Will post picture as soon as print is done. Note: Updated the file, fixed height, screwholes and wall thickness. After building and printing with the box, i realized that it needs some work, it's way too compact and some people have their pins sideways.. I will investigate it when i find the time and redo the model.

Print, preferably with 1 wall perimeter and some infill, 25% seems to work..
When it's done, mount board in box with screwholes ... No profit, cause i designed it :) Theres a hole for the screw terminal, and one for the USB port, furthermore, a hole for the cables to come through and some holes for the lid. If you have a Mendel90 or something with a 6mm thick upstanding edge, you can print the extra file for a nice mount!

description.text: The HiTechnic Sensor Multiplexer extends the LEGO Mindstorms NXT and adds extra functionality by allowing up to 4 sensors to be connected to one NXT sensor port. comments.author: galaverse

description.text:
This is a model of my son's favorite Pokeman, Quilava, done in the low-polygon style. Low Poly objects are things designed with a low amount of polygons, giving them a blocky or 8-Bit feel. They can also be easier to 3D print, as objects with millions of polygons are harder to process.
I designed Quilava using Tinkercad. After the body was roughed in, I exported an STL and imported that into Meshmixer where I decimated it (reduced the number of polygons) until it looked good. Then back into Tinkercad, where I removed it's left side, duplicated & flipped the right side and stuck it to the left, creating perfect bilateral symmetry. Then I added the flaming head fins and tail.

Prints OK with supports for the tail, torso and head. I hope to make another version soon with detached flames that could be printed separately and perhaps in different colors.

Quilava is available to copy-and-edit on Tinkercad.com: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6qJoX3eiAFW-quilava-pokemon-low-poly/edit

Neutron is one of two open source 3D printers designed by Layer One, the creator of Atom 3D Printers (Link to Proton: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2149685)

While the RepRap project produced some functional printers, it was clear that nobody had intended to produce something for the desktop of the discerning designer. That’s where Layer One’s Proton and Neutron come in. If you're an open-source advocate, a tinkerer, and a designer with an eye for aesthetics, you’ll want one of these on your desk.

All the printed parts of the printer is right here. Neutron was built in OnShape. Log in to remix your own version of Neutron, it's free as long as you share what you have made. Visit our website for the BOM, CAD files, assembly guide and everything else.

title: OpenForge 2.0 Mag Wood Floor House Stairwell Up Door Down

description.text:
OpenForge 2.0 OpenLock 4
Now with a wood floor. As there have been requests to avoid the "Down" of other tiles, I have gone with an implied downstairs terrain piece as I needed a spiral stair in the corner of a house. Avoiding a print with supports, modified a previous stair with a stone wall "stairwell" to create a roleplaying terrain feature/accessory to depict a 3/4 turn (270 deg) spiral staircase in the corner of a room. Stacking a second floor I would leave the tile missing from the corner to depict the top of the stairwell. Then again, maybe the door is just a closet.....

Recreated the spiral stair effect by xloud - Spiral Stair Up (if you notice, different treads). Set for OpenForge 2.0 (25.4mm sq tile) and able to glue to the standard E OpenLock base, or MAG base.
See here for bases:
Cut Stone http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1910969
or Plain http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1910974

Note! have not printed to verify compatibility as of 03/02/17.

Kudos to Printablescenery
http://www.printablescenery.com/product-category/rampage-system/
Rampage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821631
OpenLock 4.0 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963
and DevonJones OpenForge
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:251178

description.text:
Proton is one of two open source 3D printers designed by Layer One, the creator of Atom 3D Printers (Link to Neutron: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2149660)

While the RepRap project produced some functional printers, it was clear that nobody had intended to produce something for the desktop of the discerning designer. That’s where Layer One’s Proton and Neutron come in. If you're an open-source advocate, a tinkerer, and a designer with an eye for aesthetics, you’ll want one of these on your desk.

All the printed parts of the printer is right here. Proton was built in OnShape. Log in to remix your own version of Proton, it's free as long as you share what you have made. Visit our website for the BOM, CAD files, assembly guide and everything else.

title: Power Supply enclosure box for Elegoo Robotics Kits

description.text:
This is an enclosure for the bare power supply board shipped with many Elegoo robotics and electronics kits.

The board fits neatly in the box, and the button and top snap together, protecting your power supply from accidental shorts. There is enough clearance that you can connect patch wires inside, and a feed-through hole to route the wires to your circuits. A small button extender brings the power button outside the enclosure.

I have printed it in PETG at 200µm resolution, but other plastics (including PLA) should work as well.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

doesn't matter

Notes:

You should print the flat surfaces down on the printer bed. The button can be printed upright but must have the recessed rectangular hole on top.

I have printed this with PETG on the Original Prusa Mk II, using Slicer, and it works fine.

DO NOT use supports when printing the lid. Slicer will fill the needed airgap under the springy latch tabs, preventing them from working right.

Assembly

Fit-check the button with the lid by trying to feed it through the hole in the lid. The smooth end of the cylinder should go through the hole, and the collar and recessed-hole end should point "down" in the same direction as the support cylinder and straps on the lid. The button should slide easily through the hole. If it doesn't, sand the button or rasp the hole slightly.

Place your Elegoo power supply board (not part of the Thing) into the box and press down gently until it rests on the internal shelf, with the connectors lined up with the holes.

Fit the button extender to the pushbutton switch on the power supply board.

Gently lower the lid down over the box so that the straps mate with the cutouts on the outside of the box, and the button extender sticks through the hole.

When the lid is all the way on, make certain that the straps are latched against the sides of the box. You're done!

To open, pry the straps out slightly and slide off the lid. To remove the board, tap the box upside down on a hard flat surface.

I made this as a test design using TurboCAD for Mac. "Tight" clearances are 0.5mm to allow for printer slop. Internal shelving and small ramps position the board, which is held in place by a support rod from the lid downward. The lid is secured by springy strap latches.
NGSS CCSS

Electronics Enclosure This box shows several design principles for mechanical latches and enclosures. It is useful for the Elegoo electronics/robotics kits that have become so popular: Elegoo provides a bare power supply/regulator board, and in normal use it often sits "naked" on the table, where it can short or fall or be squished by an errant elbow. The enclosure provides mechanical support and isolation, while demonstrating some useful design techniques:
  • internal ledges and cleared areas to match the board
  • adequate clearance for connectors around the board
  • internal channels for components to clear
  • internal ramps to position the additional part (circuit board)
  • nested/interlocking elements with toleranced joints (0.5mm clearance, all gaps)
  • tension latches (on straps)
  • Use of material spring characteristics to enable mechanical actuation
  • overhanging "tables" and gussets on the latches, to enhance springiness

Basic demonstration project This is a basic demonstration project that is also useful in the context of electronics kit development. Lesson plan is to "walk through" the design features listed above, either on the STL file or on the printed article.
Requires Elegoo electronics kit The enclosure itself is designed to fit the 5V power supply board supplied with many Elegoo kits (e.g. the UNO KIT, and BEST STARTER KIT).

I designed this spool holder from scratch because I had different spools that had different center hole sizes and offsets. In particular the FlashForge Creator Pro has 2 spools, and the spool on the right side requires the spool to be mounted backwards from the left side.

I used OpenScad to make it customizable.

remixed_from.title: Wanhao Extruder Plate for Flexible Filament

description.text:
I was able to print tpu with no many issues, but Ninjaflex was always a problem.
so i decided to disassembled the plate every time the filament got stuck and always found that the filament was making a loop or exiting by the little space between the wheel and the plate. so i add a little slip that fill that space in the wheel, without affecting it and that help to no just print Ninjaflex with success, but at decent speed of 50mm/sec so far.

I recommend to use a small layer size, about 0.1 to print this plate, in abs.
i also recommend to take the time to install the tube PTFE with care, trim both of the tips to make them narrow, they both have to enter into the plate hole and also at the cooler block. Failing this guess what, the filament will start making its thing there.

i hope this help to all of you.

sorry my english. i could write this better in spanish ;)

print_settings.Notes:: Note that the heights of the nut and bolt blocks, and the thickness of the clamp ring are interdependent - too tall on the blocks, and/or too thin on the ring, and the blocks can stick up from the ring (still works, but looks ugly). I need to fillet these in smoother, to cover these other cases, at some future point. (The default ring thickness and nut/bolt block heights have worked fine for me, and print w/o any ugliness, with the default params for these features.)

description.text:
This is a highly customizable means of mounting a bicycle computer to your aerobars. Many aspects can be customized, to include:

  • clamp inner diameter (to fit your aerobar diameter)
  • clamp wall thickness
  • clamp width
  • adapter diameter (to mimic a handlebar diameter appropriate for your computer mount)
  • arm angle (to achieve the desired height above/below/at the aerobar height)
  • arm length (to allow desired horizontal positioning on aerobar)
  • height of top of adapter above arm (to again allow vertical customization)
  • channel depth/width/spacing for securing computer mount fastening straps (zip tie, rubber o-ring, etc)
  • bolt/nut dimensions (for countersink of nut and bolt)
  • fudge factor for dimensional tolerance of adapter that fits on arm (it can be hard to get a 3D printer to produce the same inner and outer dimensions for a specified value...)
  • whether to print the arm, the adapter, or both (as well as which orientation to print the adapter in - vertical or horizontal)
  • and more :-)

This can be printed in PLA or ABS, but if you anticipate possibly leaving your bike in a hot car, ABS might be better.

The round adapter piece fits over the arm of the clamp, and mine stays firmly in place as a result of the zip ties used to attach the computer mount base to the aerobar mount/adapter. It could also be glued or a small screw could be used, if desired. (Mine does not move at all, just from the zip ties, which are needed for the computer base, anyway.)

Mine is printed in ABS, and has provided a very strong, secure and rigid mount for my computer.

Someday I may print another in a different color (black? red? :-), but green was what I had on-hand at the time!

Notes:

The round adapter piece can be printed in a vertical or horizontal orientation. Less support is needed for the vertical orientation, but I've found that the horizontal position, with support, gives better results. (In horizontal orientation, the top of the round adapter is narrow, so the last part prints very quickly, resulting in that section getting a bit too hot. This may result in a ridge along the top, which might require a little work with a knife or sandpaper to smooth out, but the overall quality has been better for me in this orientation, than in a vertical orientation.)

The default values for the nut and bolt parameters are for an M4 socket head cap screw, and a nylon lock nut. Adjust as needed for your nut and bolt, but make sure that the dimensions of the clamp are sufficient for your chosen nut and bolt. (These, of course, are customizable - gotta love OpenSCAD!! :-)

Note that the heights of the nut and bolt blocks, and the thickness of the clamp ring are interdependent - too tall on the blocks, and/or too thin on the ring, and the blocks can stick up from the ring (still works, but looks ugly). I need to fillet these in smoother, to cover these other cases, at some future point. (The default ring thickness and nut/bolt block heights have worked fine for me, and print w/o any ugliness, with the default params for these features.)

This was designed using the ever and always awesome OpenSCAD tool!

As such, it can be customized here via Customizer, or you can (and are encouraged to!) download the .scad file, and OpenSCAD, and modify it to your heart's content on your computer.

The uploaded .stl files are simply for the Thingiverse preview feature - you'll want to use Customizer or OpenSCAD to modify the settings to suit your needs.

Customizable Parameters

//diameter of the bar onto which the clamp will be mounted
clampInnerDia = 22.3;
//thickness of the clamp wall wrapping around the bar
clampWallThick = 4;
//width of the clamp (ie, front-to-back, along the length of the bar) (bear in mind that this width must be greater than the bolt head and nut diameters, as they are countersunk into the clamp)
clampWidth = 12;

//length of the flat section of the arm - must be long enough to accomodate the needed adapterLen
armLen = 30;
//height of the arm (and bolt block)
armHt = 10;
//angle needed to achieve the depth above (negative angle) or below (positive angle) the bar that you need the arm to be (take into account the adapterHt value)
armAngle = -20;

//thickness of the gap between the nut and bolt blocks
blockGapThick = 3;
//width of the nut and bolt blocks (ie, distance from clamp toward arm
blockWidth = 10;
//height (thickness) of the nut block
nutBlockHt = 7;

//diameter of bolt head inset (use bolt head diameter plus 1-2mm) - must be a sensible value, as compared to clampWidth
boltHeadDia = 8;
//height of the clamp bolt head (ie, depth of the bolt head countersink)
boltHeadInset = 4;
//diameter of the shank of the bolt
boltShankDia = 4;

//circular diameter of the nut, plus about 1mm (for a 6-sided nut, the distance between 2 opposite corners on the nut, plus a little)
nutDia = 10;
//depth of the nut countersink - must be a sensible value, as compared to nutBlockHt
nutInset = 3.5;

//length of the round adapter that fits on the arm - must be long enough for bands, ties, etc that hold your computer mount on
adapterLen = 30;
//outside diameter of the adapter - such that your computer mount will sit on it well
adapterDia = 25;
//height above the top, flat surface of the arm, that the top of the adapter should be
adapterHt = 5;
//if your aerobar is at an angle, where you'll be mounting the clamp, it can cant the arm one way or the other (so your computer would sit crooked) - this allows some compensation for that, if needed
adapterAngle = 0;

adapterStrapChannelSpacing = 15.5;
adapterStrapChannelWidth = 4;
adapterStrapChannelDepth = 2;

//printers tend to over-size exterior dimensions a bit, and correspondingly undersize interior dimensions, so this
// fudge factor widens and deepens the slot in the adapter, to allow the adapter to fit onto the arm better
//use this if/as needed for your printer. Set to total mm extra width needed.
adapterInteriorFudgeFactor = .8;

//enable/disable generation of the clamp - in case only want to print one or the other
generateClamp = true;
//enable/disable generation of the adapter - in case only want to print one or the other
generateAdapter = true;

//orientation for placement of adapter on print surface - 0 = vertical, 90 = horizontal (just for printing/plating purpose)
adapterPrintOrientation = 0;

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the Zero Force Motor Replication Attachment for: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2149044
The Zero Force Motor is discussed here: http://www.energyscienceforum.com/showthread.php?t=3384

The magnets for the rotor are .75" X .25" neodymium disc and can be sourced from: http://www.magnet4less.com/index.php?cPath=1_11&osCsid=qj2bnener22h4ginvbus1rqe17
They have N42 or N52

There are two .125" set screw holes in the rotor
The shaft size should be 1/4"

Disclaimer: Catastrophic failure of parts spinning at high speed can cause damage to property, personal injury, or death. You build and experiment with this motor at your own risk.

both parts will require you to print with support on the bottom

I would suggest using 1/8" brass or wooden tabs to attach this part. Steel threaded rod may interfere with the efficiency of the motor.

03/03/2017 : A new rotor was added with more options. You can use the neo magnets with the holes in the middle to better secure in the rotor. http://www.magnet4less.com/product_info.php?cPath=1_128&products_id=1264 or http://www.magnet4less.com/product_info.php?cPath=1_128&products_id=1023

3/5/2017: I added a third option for a rotor. You will be able to fit up to a 3/4" X 3/4" magnet in the slots.

description.text:
I was printing a house key from nrp's post http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8925 for my wife. Of course she said, "No not like that, AAA gives them to me in a credit card so I can put it in my wallet" so I made her one. Then I though some others might want that too so here we go.

This is currently only for kwikset locks, in particular kw1 keys but I do plan on adding Schlage and others I find so I will keep it listed as a work in progress for a bit.
EDIT - no need for me to add the Schlage, Elliotboney did it already here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172648

You will need to print the key guage posted by LBussy http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2086917

Once that is printed, you need to get 5 numbers. You get these numbers by running your key into the guage to determine each "gap" in the key. The first number is the gap closest to the grip. Enter those 5 numbers and print.

This is a plastic key so I do recommend using in emergencies only, but I have tested with my kwikset locks and every print has worked flawlessly on the locks.

title: Filament fan duct (Re-D-Bot, for E3D V6 and Volcano)

description.text:
Hello my friends! (=

After a few months, I understood need to try another fans, instead 4010 model. So I bought radial fans, and I designed the new fan holder. What can I say... It's AWESOME! Super flow and without cooling of hotend.

If you using x carriage for Re-D-Bot, and you want use new fan holder with volcano, I recommend increase holes (bellow you can find image) or use updated version (Carriage_base_back.STL you can find there).

This fans is pretty powerful, and main printing going on 40-50% of fan power. If you want reduce noise of fans, in Marlin you can turn on sofware PWM for fans. You need uncomment this in Configuration.h

#define FAN_SOFT_PWM

Video of print test: https://youtu.be/MXtuoXqMKMM

title: iPhone USB Cable Protector

description.text:
After breaking almost uncounted iphone usb cables!! I designed this using Fusion 360 to save my newly purchased charging cables.

Download Fusion 360
http://www.autodesk.com/products/fusion-360/overview

Notes:-

  • Scale the design by x1.1 if you find difficulty in fitting.
  • I haven't tried printing it with different materials, specially flexible material like ninjaflex. Keep me posted if anyone prints it in different material.
  • If you want to update or modify the design then I wont mind sharing the original .f3d files, ping me if you need it.
  • I would be more than happy if you share this design within your network so that more people can 3D Print it and save their charging cables.
  • Do not forget to tag me while doing a social media shoutout @varunheta

Recommended settings for decent quality 3D prints:

  • Layer height: 0.2mm
  • Infill Density: 15%
  • Shell Thickness: 0.8mm
  • Material: PLA or ABS
  • Print Speed: Not more than 40mm/s
  • Supports: No
  • Orientation: Upside Down Vertical Position
  • Rafts: Yes

Let me know if there is anything else you would like to know about the design. I am more than happy to assist you all.
Cheers

MakerBot

0.1

100%

comments.text: This was one of the first things I printed when I got my A8 back in Aug - Sept.  Been running strong, however I did just observe one issue that may be causing my prints to come out a bit jittery.  The holes where the 3mm bolt goes through to hold the idler pulley has gotten a bit loose.  I can actually move the idler pully a little bit by pushing the screw-head and this can't be good for the outcome of my prints.  It's just from wear-and-tear - the PLA has stretched a bit.  (countless hours spent watching beavis and butthead as a child is making me want to laugh at everything i just said... loose stretched holes and screw heads and, oh nevermind...)

comments.text:
I printed it in ABS & I always find ABS holes seem to shrink 8-10% , so i was ex­pecting to have to scale it a little ,but it all worked nice .
I just modded my A8 to take a 200 x 300 hotbed , which is working well.
comments.author: CH35C0

comments.text: looks great! what did you do to enlarge it? did you modify firmware or only hardware?
comments.author: sportssedan

comments.text:
Yes, it was fairly involved , Had to mod everything . Firmware needed changing for all the new parameters for bed & axis movement , Auto bed leveling co-ordinates & lots of mods to the startup G code, & then tune it all. Hardware took a month to build & accumulate all the necessary parts , like the larger bed , new bigger power supply , mosfets , wiring etc, & the hardware . Needed new M8 joining rods , linear shafts & then had to design & print parts like a frame extension , cable duct , & also fabricate a new aluminium table base etc.
Once i had everything done it only took an evening to convert it all, but many hours of prep . Happy with the result , much more versatile machine now but a fairly complex upgrade .
comments.author: CH35C0

comments.text:
that sure is a lot of work but it's worth it! now you can print larger objects without having to slice and glue them so much and that great!!
really..good job!
comments.author: sportssedan

comments.text: Yep , already printed some 300mm long parts , so worth tbe effort.☺

comments.text: I typical newbie question......   Anet A8 - hotbed plate 220 x220  on the diagonal it should fit . Cura scales it down to around 176mm and I have  not found a way to re-scale it and turn it 45 degrees on the diagonal. Slicr Also seems to  start it at 176 and scalling x125 give more or less the  right dimensions - in theory... but its  will cut off on one end or the  other ! So how do I get to print it fit the frame?
comments.author: ABW-3D

comments.text: I'm a newbie too so don't worry. what frame are you trying to print? the same one I have in my pictures? if you open it in cura it says that it's been scaled to 74%. click on the object and go to the SCALE button on the left and then insteadd of the 74,41% that you should have put 100%. Then click the button under it and rotate 45º. after that move it manually (auto center doesn't work for this model so don't even bother trying it) and done.

This thing was made with BlocksCAD

Edit this project at BlocksCAD: https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor?from=32381
Or, download the .xml file and load it at: https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor

Printed in Torwell's purple PLA.

This was not made with any parametric software!!

This was done manually in 10 minutes. It is not hard to make things hairy, you just need to know how to duplicate and rotate objects in your chosen modelling program. PM me if you want to know how it's done the quick way.

In the Hairy Walrus make I did, lowlight said "hmmm this makes me think of Unicorn manes/tails and gnome beards cant be far off in the future."

and I thought yeah that's actually a good idea and so here is a Hairy Unicorn. If you have a good idea for something hairy let me know in the comments and it might make the next one! Perhaps the gnome next who knows if I can get some time.

This is a pretty simple and quick print, mine took 1 hour and 48 minutes.

No supports required as you can see from the photo.

Increase bridging speed by 150% at least, cooling essential.

If you are printing this at 0.3mm layer height the hair will be fairly brittle, but if you print it at 0.2 it will do 2 passes on each hair so they wont break at all when you go to mold them.

Very hot water in a bowl, dip hair in for a few seconds and then shape.

title: Wabbajack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"Wonderful! Time for a celebration... Cheese for everyone!"  (Sheogorath)
 Hello everyone.  And welcome to a day of printing madness, as Sheogorath would probably say.  
 Today I offer up the famed Wabbajack staff.  No need to solve any of his riddles, just download, scale, print, and assemble.
 I pulled this straight from Skyrim, and cut it into pieces so it could be printed on almost any printer.  I used Cura, and scaled each piece by 7.  That way, once assembled, it would be close to the size it looks in the game.
 The pieces are labeled, from top to bottom in numerical order 1-9.  
 I'm printing it in Inland black PLA, 1.75mm, at 100 mm/s.  I did use supports on the top piece, touching build plate.  All other parts do not need support.    
 I will add more photos once mine is finished and painted, and Ive transformed my first victim into a tasty Sweet Roll.   
 If you like this or would like the files edited, please leave a comment and I'll do my best.
 Also, feel free to make any special requests for other items.  I don't mind at all, and would be happy to oblige.

comments.text: I ordered one of the v2 LED separators from a 3D print service in abs plastic. I cannot recommend this modified separator because I could only apply it with extreme force because it's too narrow. It bent the LEDs A+B a bit sideways so that now the cut-outs on the front cover don't match anymore which is not good. Also I had to remove the mainboard because otherwise I risked breaking it because it bent so much when I tried to push it downwards. This separator needs to be widened a bit or don't use strong plastic like ABS use something that bends better because this thing doesn't completely fit. I have it applied now even though LEDs A+B are no snapping into the cut-outs but I'd rather leave it like it is then risking to damage the device if I try to remove it.

title: FLSUN Kossel Mini Self Level No Spring Effector Set

description.text:
I wasn't happy with the effector that came with the FLSUN Kossel Mini. I especially did not like the fact that they used a spring to actively push the nozzle down as this is causing to much strain which warps the heat bed while leveling. Gravity and the tension of the sensor spring is enough for the nozzle to come down again.

Because the released files are of terrible quality I fully recreated the whole set, now without the spring. The design also prevents the nozzle from going down to much.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8vhHDzPpiS7

comments.text: I am repairing a seriously broken FLSUN Kossel for someone and the effector is destroyed. (Don't ask). Question, How do I mount the plastic cooling to this?
comments.author: WombatBA

comments.text: Cooling is attached to the extruder itself. Have a look over here (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:780379) for an example. Make sure however that you have the same extruder and fan size!
comments.author: WombatBA

comments.text: i am missing the whole to run the cables down to the heatblock. if i run the cables outside the effector the whole thing will "tilt" while moving
comments.author: Mike1960

comments.text: The hole to run the wires through is left out on purpose as I don't like to put wires through a hole between two moving parts(as in the original) because it might jam the movement or damage the wires. Adding a hole also affects the rigidity of the effector. I like to attach the wires to one of the rods and (if attached high enough) don't experience any tilting at all.

title: Bowden Central Carriage for "X3D CoreXY by Unix"

description.text:
Rework of Central Carriage from project "X3D XS CoreXY by Unix"
Made for use with bowden extruder.
In my printer it works with this extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275593

EDIT april, 3, 2017:
This carriage is tested and proven to fit and work, although I've had big problems with printing quality and oozing caused by play in indirect bowden system. I think it is more resonable to use lightweight NEMA 17 motor with original direct extruder carriage instead of this. (File named central_carriage in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:730199/#files)
My advice: only use bowden feed extruder if you for some reason really need it. Direct is better in spite of his downside (weight).

title: Kossel Mini NEMA17 Extruder for 1.75mm Filament

description.text:
Johann's original Extruder uses stepper motor with Planetary Gearbox (5:1 ratio). It is an excellent minimalist design which works reliably. This is a modified version which uses standard NEMA17 which is good enough to do the job. www.blomker.com Parts list : 1pc NEMA 17 Stepper Motor
1pc Drive Gear (11mm diameter)
1pc 625ZZ Bearing
1pc Push fit connector (M5 thread)
1pc M5 x 16mm cap screw
1pc M5 Nut
3pcs M3 x 10mm cap screw
Assemble the extruder based on the pictures.

title: Hictop Left Side X & Z Axis Lift Screw

description.text:
I modified the Left X & Z Axis Lift Screw for the Hictop i3 style printer. I widened the holes for the stepper motor left to right so that you could loosen the screws and slide the motor to the left, looking at the front of the printer for tensioning of the X-Axis Belt.

Added tie down point for cable management.

Added holes so that you can tie down the wire coming off of the x limit switch so it doesn't break.

I recommend 100% infill printed in ABS.

description.text:
EDIT: For a new and improved version with adjustability, go here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2795998

EDIT: Revision 3 of 45deg stand to improve stability.

EDIT: Revision 2 is now available. I have narrowed the design and reduced some dimensions to make them more compact.

This stand for the Nintendo Switch allows for the device to be charged while using a stand other than the official Nintendo Switch dock.

Ideal for use when on the go and wanting to play in portable mode without holding the device and requiring the system to charge in the process. Design allows for a battery pack to be tucked in behind the Switch (Anker 20100+ Powerpack shown in Photos, ideal for the Switch).

The standard Switch stand does not allow for simultaneous charging while the stand is in use.

There are 3 versions:
• NS-S0300-2_SwitchStand-35deg - Ideal for use on planes where you're positioned close and above the device (when resting on tray table).

• NS-S0301-3_SwitchStand-45deg - Ideal if sitting close to the device,

• NS-S0302-2_SwitchStand-70deg - Similar angle to the standard Switch stand.

Nicely made, and works well!
However, at least for the 70 deg version, the official power cord does not fit underneath. The stand stops exactly where the softer wire begins. A slightly higher-up version would solve this. Being able to make the cord go towards the back instead of only the front would also be a plus I think (e.g. a small hole in the bottom back for the cord to go through)! :-)

comments.text:
That'd be nice, yeah! I think just about a centimeter or so should do the trick.
You could keep it simple by giving the back part of the stand the same "middle gap" as the front has... That way no matter how anyone wants to use it, setting it up should take no more than a second or two. And the extra space in the middle means a powerbank could still sit on top of the cord.

description.text:
This is a headphones holder for my Ikea SKARSTA desk, which is a stand-up desk with modular height.

The stand uses two holes present on the main structure and is fully 3d-printed (no other parts needed).

Sorry for the mess on the pictures :)

To print it directly

  • Print stand.stl x 1
  • Print full_screw.stl x 2

For advanced configuration

You need to download headphones_holder_config.scad + stand.scad. You'll also need screw_base.stl (except if you want to customize the screws as well, in this case use screw.scad to make your owns).
All files must be in the same directory.

Credits

Thanks to Dan Kirshner for the OpenSCAD threads library

Dagoma DiscoEasy200

title: HIctop i3 Y Carriage Limit Switch Belt Clip

description.text:
I redesigned the y-belt clip and limit switch. I did not like the y limit switch being in the middle of the moving bed. I have my wires break a few times. I designed a bracket you can attach to the y motor to and mount the switch to it. you can then zip tie the wire down and it doesn't move or need to be repaired.

The belt clip was modified to allow for m3 screws to clamp down on the belts so the stay put. careful to only tighten the screws slightly snug or you will break the ABS Part. I replace the switch with a arm that triggers the y limit switch.

I recommend 100% infill printed in ABS.

Panzergranate 39 or Pzgr. 39 was a German armor-piercing shell used during World War II. It was manufactured in various calibers and was the most common anti-tank shell used in German tank (German: Kampfwagenkanone; shorted to KwK) and anti-tank guns (German: Panzerabwehrkanone(n); shortened to PaK) of 37 to 88 mm (1.5 to 3.5 in) caliber.

This model has been made with Historical Schematics and dimensions, and it's belived to be 100% Historically accurate.

Does not include Tracer pod
